CENPES - Research and Development Center Rio de Janeiro RJ Brazil Graphical abstract The development of new matrices can improve the hydrothermal stability of fluid catalytic cracking catalysts and provide better selectivity to cracking products. Amorphous, mesoporous and stoichiometric aluminum phosphate (AlPO4) was investigated as active matrix to achieve these purposes. In its gel form, the material was initially added to ultra-stabilized Y zeolite to generate composites with mass ratio of about 1:1. The interaction between AlPO4 and Y zeolite avoided AlPO4 crystallization during steaming and increased framework aluminum retention, preserving more Brönsted acid sites. A spray-dried catalyst containing AlPO4 was steam deactivated and tested by vacuum gas oil cracking, being compared with an alumina-containing catalyst and a reference without active matrix. AlPO4-containing catalyst presented tolerance to contaminant metals, higher selectivity to naphtha yields and exhibited a higher hydrogen transfer reaction rate, leading to the increase in isoparaffins and aromatics yields and the increase in the motor octane number in the cracked naphtha. Keywords Fluid catalytic cracking Aluminum phosphate Y zeolite Hydrothermal stability Hydrogen transfer reaction 1 Introduction Fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) is a remarkable and profitable conversion process in oil refineries as it turns heavy and low-priced feedstock into more valuable products, mainly gasoline and LPG (liquefied petroleum gas). The two basic FCC catalyst constituents are the Y zeolite in its ultra-stable form (USY), often exchanged with lanthanum (REUSY), and the matrix. The REUSY counts on strong Brönsted acid sites that promote cracking of hydrocarbon molecules and pore shape that conducts the selectivity to cracking products [1–4]. The matrix is typically composed of clay, usually kaolin, alumina and silica. Kaolin [Al2(OH)4(Si2O5)] provides density and mechanical resistance to the particles [1,2]. Silica sol, peptized pseudoboehmite alumina (AlOOH.nH2O) or aluminum chlorohydrol [Al2Cl(OH)5] may be used as binding agents, linking all ingredients cohesively and keeping the catalyst integrity preserved [2]. Alumina provides a porous and acidic system that enables the pre-cracking of heavy molecules [1,4], whereas silica can interact with alumina at high temperatures, generating tetrahedrally coordinated silica-alumina species on the alumina surface to produce Brönsted acid sites and a more active cracking surface [2,5]. Although extensive research has been devoted to the development of zeolites to improve catalyst activity and selectivity, studies related to the interaction of matrix constituents with zeolites as well as to the development of new matrices have received less attention. Matrices can provide benefits such as reduced coke yield, increased liquid products yields, higher hydrothermal stability and tolerance to contaminant metals [2,3,6]. Described as catalyst for different reactions [7–11], aluminum phosphate (AlPO4) is a potential alternative material to be employed as active matrix in FCC catalysts. Since physical-chemical, textural and catalytic features of aluminum phosphates are controlled by varying Al/P molar ratio, pH and thermal treatment [12–14], these synthesis parameters can be investigated aiming to produce a proper material with unique porosity and acidity that outperform conventional alumina-based materials as active matrix for FCC catalysts. It is well-known that P-modified ZSM-5 by means of the addition of small amounts of mono-aluminum phosphate (MAP) or H3PO4 (0.5–3.0 wt.% P) exhibits an improved hydrothermal stability, retaining more Brönsted acid sites and catalytic cracking activity than the unmodified counterpart [15–19]. Positive effects of phosphorus on USY have also been reported. For example, Saka et al. found that a catalyst containing USY modified with 2 wt.% phosphorus achieved higher cracking activity and higher octane number of cracked naphtha, since phosphorus suppressed zeolite collapse under hydrothermal conditions [20]. Nevertheless, a phosphorus content of 6.0 wt.% may cause significant zeolite dealumination under steaming, concomitantly with the interaction between phosphorus and extra framework Al (EFAL), thus forming amorphous AlPO4 species and reducing the overall acidity density and strength [21]. Therefore, aiming the synthesis of catalysts containing USY and a high percentage of AlPO4 in an acidic environment, the effect of the intimate contact between these components is a matter of investigation. Several examples in the literature describe catalysts or additives containing AlPO4 as matrix, but the zeolitic compound is ZSM-5 or other zeolites of high Si/Al ratio, not much vulnerable to acidic attack [22–25]. In these cases, aluminum phosphate is formed in situ from the reaction between Al and P sources or its gel is mixed with the zeolite slurry. Regarding the cases where AlPO4 was studied within USY catalysts, Roberie et al. produced a spray-dried catalyst containing 25 wt.% AlPO4, 60 wt.% USY of high Si/Al ratio and kaolin, which was blended with a commercial catalyst and tested as an additive [26]. As compared to the commercial catalyst, the blend containing 10 wt.% additive presented higher activity, lower hydrogen yield and equivalent motor octane number for the C5+ gasoline fractions. In turn, Walker et al. and Corma et al. claimed that samples containing USY and AlPO4 were more active for heavy feedstock cracking than the counterparts without AlPO4 [27,28]. However, the evaluated samples of both groups did not comprise the typical zeolite-matrix composition of a FCC catalyst inasmuch as clay and binder constituents were not added to those samples. Silica sol can lead to zeolite dealumination [29,30], and its residual sodium neutralizes the zeolite acid sites [6,31], whereas the contact between kaolin and zeolite generates solid-state interfacial reactions that can lead to a decrease in Brönsted acidity, impacting on catalyst performance [32]. Walker et al. preferred AlPO4 with an Al/P ratio from 0.9 to 1.0, whereas Corma et al. indicated Al/P ratio higher than 1.0. In Walker’s work, the AlPO4-containing sample led to higher coke yield and no data concerning products yields was reported by Corma et al. The objective of the present work is to develop FCC catalysts containing AlPO4 as active matrix. Aluminum phosphate was prepared under low pH with Al/P molar ratio 1.0. The respective AlPO4-REUSY composite with mass ratio of about 1:1 was characterized by N2 physisorption and XRD to investigate the effect of AlPO4 on the zeolite crystallinity. Solid-state MAS NMR techniques were applied to AlPO4 and its composite with REUSY for a detailed investigation of the zeolite hydrothermal stability provided by AlPO4. AlPO4 was also investigated by DRIFT with pyridine adsorption. A simplified procedure was employed for the preparation of a spray-dried catalyst containing 20 wt.% stoichiometric AlPO4 and 40 wt.% REUSY. The produced FCC catalyst was steam deactivated, without and with contaminant metals (nickel, vanadium), and tested by vacuum gas oil (VGO) cracking, with the liquid products analyzed by PIANIO. The AlPO4 catalyst was compared to an alumina-containing catalyst and a reference without active matrix. The number of Brönsted acid sites of the deactivated catalysts was determined by n-propylamine-TPD in order to observe the influence of active matrices on catalyst acidity. The correlation between samples characterization and catalytic evaluation results was discussed as well. 2 Experimental 2.1 Lab-scale samples Aluminum phosphate sample with Al/P molar ratio 1.0 was prepared via sol-gel route, based on the literature [7,11,14]. A brief procedure of the synthesis is described as follows. The volume equivalent to 19.0 g of phosphoric acid (85 wt.%) was added to a solution containing 61.1 g of aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3.9H2O) in 150 mL of distilled water under stirring. The pH was adjusted to 3.5 by addition of 20 wt.% aqueous ammonia solution. After 4 h of stirring at room temperature, the mixture was oven dried at 110 °C. The dried solid was calcined at 600 °C for 1 h. A composite consisting of stoichiometric AlPO4 and REUSY with a mass ratio of approximately 1:1 was prepared by adding an aqueous slurry of REUSY to the mixture of aluminum nitrate and phosphoric acid at pH 3.5 prepared as mentioned above. After 30 min of stirring at room temperature, the final slurry was oven dried at 110 °C and the resultant solid was calcined at 600 °C for 1 h. The stoichiometric aluminum phosphate and the corresponding zeolitic composite were designated as AlPO and AlPO-REUSY. The parent REUSY, synthesized in Petrobras R&D facilities, was submitted to the same treatment of resuspension in water, drying and calcination used for the composite, generating the REUSY powder sample applied as reference for characterizations. All calcined (fresh) samples were deactivated by means of hydrothermal treatment on a Carbolite HZS 12/900 split tube furnace at 800 °C for 5 h under 100 % steam flow, providing the corresponding deactivated samples suffixed with (-d): AlPO-d, AlPO-REUSY-d and REUSY-d. This deactivation was performed at high temperature in the presence of steam to simulate the operational conditions to which the catalyst is exposed in a FCC unit. It is worthy of mention that aluminum phosphates with different Al/P molar ratios, i.e., Al/P 0.8 and Al/P 1.2, and their respective composites with REUSY, were prepared similarly and submitted to the same characterizations. Notwithstanding, this work is focused on AlPO4 samples with stoichiometric Al/P ratio, since they have provided the best results. 2.2 Pilot plant-scale catalysts A set of FCC catalysts was prepared at Petrobras R&D Center pilot-plant facilities. REUSY, kaolin and aluminum phosphate (or peptized pseudoboehmite) aqueous slurries were added to the silica sol, used as the binding agent. The final mixture was spray-dried at an outlet temperature of approximately 135 °C. The resulting fine powder was washed with ammonium sulfate aqueous solution for the removal of sodium [2]. This procedure, described in detail in Supplementary Information, Section 1, consisted of resuspending the catalyst in ammonium hydroxide solution, filtering the slurry and washing the solid with the ammonium sulfate solution. After that, the catalyst was water washed, dried at 120 °C overnight and calcined at 600 °C for 1 h. The catalyst taken as reference was prepared with no active matrix, i.e., it was composed of REUSY, silica sol and kaolin. The synthesis of silica sol is described elsewhere [2]. Pseudoboehmite aqueous slurry was peptized by adding HNO3 solution until pH 2.0. In a simplified procedure for the AlPO4-containing catalyst preparation, a mixture composed of aluminum nitrate and phosphoric acid with Al/P molar ratio 1.0 at pH 3.5 was aged for 4 h under stirring at room temperature and then directly added to the other ingredient slurries. The calcined (fresh) catalysts were designated as CAT-P (prepared with AlPO4), CAT-A (prepared with peptized pseudoboehmite) and CAT-R (reference). Their respective formulations are described in Table 1 . In order to mimic catalyst contamination with organometallic molecules present in the feedstock, a certain amount of each fresh (calcined) catalyst was doped with 0.1 wt.% nickel and 0.1 wt.% vanadium by incipient wetness impregnation with aqueous solutions of nickel nitrate and vanadyl sulfate. Then, the samples were dried at 120 °C overnight, thereby generating the impregnated catalysts. Fresh and impregnated catalysts were deactivated on a fixed-bed steaming unit at 788 °C for 5 h under 100 % steam flow. The resulting deactivated catalysts were designated as CAT-d (if not impregnated with Ni and V) and CAT-i (previously impregnated with Ni and V). Deactivated catalysts were submitted to catalytic evaluation (Section 2.4). 2.3 Characterization Elemental analysis of solid samples was determined on a Panalytical Axios Max wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) operating at 25 kV, 160 mA and equipped with rhodium X-ray tube anode. Samples were fused to obtain flat glass beads, which were analyzed according to standard quantitative method (ASTM D7085) after proper instrument calibration. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation generated at 40 kV and 20 mA. The 2θ value was scanned from 5° to 80° at a speed of 0.02° s−1. The relative zeolite crystallinity was estimated from the integrated areas under the diffraction peaks assigned to the (220), (311), (331), (511), (642), (733), (555) and (664) reflections. Obtained areas were compared to that of the reference REUSY, regarded as 100 % of crystallinity. Textural characterization was obtained from low temperature (-196 °C) N2 physisorption isotherms performed on a Micromeritics 3020 TriStar analyzer, after pretreatment of the sample at 300 °C under vacuum for 1 h. BET specific area was determined from the relative pressure range (P/Po) of 0.05 – 0.20. Micropore volume and external area were determined from t-plot method considering the statistical thickness range of 3.2–5.5 Å. Mesopore size distribution and pore volume within the diameter range from 20 to 600 Å were obtained from the isotherm’s adsorption branch by using the classical BJH method. Solid-state magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MAS NMR) experiments were performed at 9.4 T on an Agilent DD2−400 spectrometer at room temperature. 1H MAS NMR spectra were acquired at a frequency of 399.71 MHz with a Hahn-echo pulse sequence, central-transition-selective (π/2x-τ1-πy-τ2-aq) at a spinning rate of 10 kHz, 4.0 mm probe and 3.5 μs and 7.0 μs pulses length. 27Al NMR spectra were recorded at a frequency of 103.89 MHz, spinning rate of 12 kHz, 4.0 mm probe and single pulse sequence with a π/20 pulse of 0.9 μs length. 27Al multiple quantum MAS NMR spectrum (27Al 3QMAS) was recorded at 103.89 MHz, spinning rate of 14 kHz, 4.0 mm probe and the excitation, conversion and z-filter were performed using a z-filtered pulse sequence, mqmas3qzf2d, with optimized pw1X; pw2X and pwXzfel of 2.7 μs; 0.9 μs and 10.0 μs, respectively. 29Si MAS NMR spectra were acquired at a frequency of 79.21 MHz, spinning rate of 5.0 kHz, 7.5 mm probe and single pulse sequence with a π/2 pulse of 5.5 μs length. 31P MAS NMR spectra were acquired at a frequency of 161.40 MHz, spinning rate of 12 kHz, 4.0 mm probe and a single pulse sequence with a p/2 pulse of 2.5 μ length. 1H, 27Al, 29Si and 31P MAS NMR chemical shifts were reported relative to tetramethylsilane, AlCl3.6H2O, kaolinite and H3PO4 85 wt.%, respectively. Spectra deconvolutions were performed by using the ssNake software [33]. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) structural spectra and the nature of acid sites after pyridine adsorption were investigated on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer with a MCT (HgCdTe) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. An accessory for diffuse reflectance from Harricks with a Praying Mantis geometry and CaF windows was coupled to the spectrometer. Spectra were collected over the wavenumber range of 4000 – 1000 cm−1 by accumulating 64 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. The sample was evacuated at 500 °C for 1 h prior to recording its structural spectrum. The temperature was cooled to 150 °C under vacuum and then vapor of pyridine at 0 °C was admitted to the sample for 15 min. The sample compartment was purged with an inert gas flow and subsequent evacuation before recording the spectrum. Temperature was raised to 250 °C, 350 °C and 450 °C under vacuum for pyridine desorption. One spectrum was recorded at each temperature. Quantification of Brönsted acid sites was performed by n-propylamine temperature programmed desorption (TPD) on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus coupled to a Pfeiffer Vacuum Omni Star mass spectrometer. The sample was pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h under helium stream and cooled down to 100 °C. Then, the sample received pulses of 0.5 cm3 of helium saturated with n-propylamine. The physically adsorbed n-propylamine was removed by heating at 200 °C for 1 h under helium stream. Then, the sample was heated up to 500 °C at the rate of 10 °C min−1 and the system was kept in isotherm for 1 h. Ammonia and propene, products of n-propylamine decomposition via the Hofmann-elimination reaction [34], were monitored by a mass spectrometer. The number of Brönsted sites was determined from the correlation between the integrated area under the curve of desorbed propene obtained for a certain mass of catalyst and the integrated area under the curve generated by a known volume of propene during instrument calibration (m/z = 41). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of AlPO4 were collected on a Tescan VEGA3 scanning emission microscope operating at 20 keV. Samples were previously metalized with gold for the increase in conductivity. Elemental mapping was obtained with a Bruker XFlash 630 M energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) detector. Samples were previously metallized by sputtering with gold on a Denton Vacuum Desk V.A. instrument. Particle size distribution of catalysts was obtained on a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser diffraction instrument with two light sources: red helium-neon laser with 4 mW power and beam wavelength of 632.8 nm and blue solid-state light with 10 mW power and beam wavelength of 470 nm. The scattering of particles was predicted by the Mie scattering model. Attrition test was conducted on a specific apparatus built in Petrobras R&D facilities according to ASTM D5757. Catalyst pretreatment consisted of sieving for removing particles higher than 180 μm and adding of 5 g of distilled water to 50.0 g of the sieved catalyst to minimize electrostatic effects. Each sample was loaded into the apparatus for testing under fluidized air flow rate of 10.6 N L min−1 for 5 h. Attrition index (AI) is reported as a dimensionless value equivalent to the percentage of catalyst loss relative to the initial mass due to the generation of fines. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic evaluation was performed on a fixed fluidized-bed ACE (Advanced Cracking Evaluation) unit from Kayser Technology. Each sample was evaluated in quintuplicate. For each experiment, 9 g of deactivated catalyst was loaded into the reactor at 535 °C and a typical Brazilian vacuum gas oil feedstock (Table S1) was injected at a constant flow rate of 0.02 g s−1 to maintain a CTO (catalyst-to-oil) mass ratio of 6.0. At the end of the reaction, the catalyst was stripped with nitrogen for recovery of entrapped hydrocarbons. The amount of coke was measured by combustion method on a LECO instrument. The gaseous effluents (H2, C1 – C5) were collected in a gas bottle and analyzed on an Agilent 3000A micro gas chromatograph with four thermal conductivity detectors and four columns: molecular sieve 5A plot, alumina plot, plot U and OV-1. The liquid effluents were collected in a specific flask, cooled by a thermostatic bath and analyzed on an Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph configured with a flame ionization detector and a HP-1 methyl silicon column. The vaporization temperature ranges for the determination of naphtha, LCO (light cycle oil) and bottoms yields were < 216 °C, 216–344 °C and > 344 °C, respectively. Naphtha fraction (C5 – C12) was analyzed according to the PIANIO method (ASTM D5134) to quantify paraffins, isoparaffins, aromatics, naphthenes, iso-olefins and olefins yields on an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph with flame ionization detector and a PONA methyl silicon column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Lab-scale samples 3.1.1 Fresh and deactivated AlPO Textural and chemical properties of fresh (AlPO) and deactivated (AlPO-d) samples are displayed in Table 2 . AlPO exhibits type IV isotherm with a high mesopore volume and a broad pore size distribution with an average size of 199 Å (Fig. 1 ). Micropores are virtually absent in this sample. The XRD pattern presents a broad band in the 2θ range between 15° and 30° that indicates the formation of an amorphous AlPO4 structure (Fig. 2 ) [8,10,14]. No signal could be related to segregated Al2O3 or P2O5 phases. According to these results, the fresh material can be identified as an amorphous mesoporous aluminum phosphate [8,14]. On its turn, XRD pattern of AlPO-d exhibits an intense peak at 2θ = 21.8° and less intense peaks at 2θ = 20.5° and 23.3°, which evidences the change of the amorphous structure of fresh AlPO into the crystalline cristobalite (21.8°) and tridymite phases after deactivation treatment (Fig. 2) [35]. The formation of crystalline phases is accompanied by the drastic reduction in specific area and porosity. SEM-EDS images of AlPO indicate a homogeneous distribution of Al and P atoms over the particles, corroborating XRD data on the absence of segregated Al2O3 and P2O5 phases (Fig. 3 ). Solid-state MAS NMR spectra reveal different types of Al and P existent in fresh AlPO. 27Al MAS NMR and 31P MAS NMR spectra are shown in Fig. 4 and the relative percentages of detected Al and P species are described in Tables 3 and 4 , with relative experimental error of ± 10 %. According to Fig. 4a, the chemical shift at 38 ppm is assigned to tetrahedral Al in the vicinity of P atoms (Altet-O-P), as in crystalline AlPO4 domains [7,14,36,37]. The peak at -12 ppm is related to octahedral Al species (Aloct-O-P) [7,14,37] and the minor resonance at 12 ppm can be attributed to intermediate species (Alint) [7,14]. 31P MAS NMR spectrum consists of a broad signal that covers overlapped peaks at approximately -10, -16, -23 and -28 ppm (Fig. 4b). Phosphorus sites are denoted as Q P m n , where n and m represent the number of POP and P-O-Al connectivities, respectively, with given tetrahedrally coordinated phosphorus [36]. The signal at -10 ppm likely represents terminal polyphosphate groups Q P 0 1 and/or Q P 1 0 , whereas the resonance at -16 ppm may be attributed to Q P 0 2 type species in the middle groups of polyphosphate chains [36]. The signal observed at -23 ppm is assigned to amorphous AlPO4 [21,37], and the peak at -28 ppm is related to the occurrence of crystalline aluminum phosphate phase [8,21]. The deconvoluted peaks in 31P MAS NMR spectra are shown in Fig. S1a-b. Schematic representation of polyphosphates is found in [38]. Regarding the deactivated sample, AlPO-d, the narrow and intense signals observed in 27Al MAS NMR (40 ppm) and 31P MAS NMR (-27 ppm) spectra refer to the occurrence of crystalline AlPO4 (Fig. 4a-b). 31P MAS NMR spectrum presents a shoulder at -30 ppm also relative to crystalline AlPO4, in accordance with its XRD pattern that indicated the existence of tridymite and cristobalite phases [8]. The structural DRIFT spectra in the −OH stretching mode range of AlPO and AlPO-d are presented in Fig. 5 a. The well-defined band at 3673 cm−1 is assigned to non-bonded surface POH groups, and a broad band in the range of 3500 – 3650 cm−1 is related to surface hydroxyl groups, most likely POH, perturbed by hydrogen bonding from neighbor surface hydroxyl groups [7,8,10,21]. The weak bands at 3711 and 3751 cm-1 are attributed to isolated Al−OH sites [39]. AlPO-d does not exhibit any band in this region, evidencing that AlPO4 crystallization due to deactivation occurs via full condensation of hydroxyl groups [8]. The nature of the acid sites on fresh AlPO surface was investigated by DRIFT with adsorption of pyridine (Fig. 5b). All bands related to −OH sites disappeared after Py adsorption (not shown), indicating that these hydroxyls are acidic and accessible sites. The spectrum collected at 150 °C shows bands at 1455, 1492 and 1631 cm−1 that correspond to Lewis acid sites. The bands at 1492, 1558 and 1643 cm−1, besides the shoulder at 1540 cm−1, reveal the presence of Brönsted sites [39,40]. The band at 1558 cm−1 remained stable until the desorption temperature of 350 °C, suggesting that this group has considerable acidic strength. The existence of Brönsted acidity in this sample was confirmed by n-propylamine-TPD experiment, which resulted in 29 μmol g−1 of these acid sites. DRIFT results show that hydroxyl groups are quite stable and provide surface Brönsted acidity to fresh AlPO. Lewis acid sites are created by sample dehydroxylation and the consequent generation of Al coordinatively unsaturated sites (cus Al) [4,40,41]. The number and proportion of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites in amorphous AlPO4 are related to the number and distribution of hydroxyl and cus Al sites, which are determined by the thermal treatment conditions adopted: time and temperature of calcination and the presence of steam. 3.1.2 Fresh and deactivated REUSY and AlPO-REUSY composite Table 2 shows the textural and chemical properties of REUSY and the composite AlPO-REUSY in the fresh and deactivated states. Based on the amounts of SiO2 and RE2O3 determined by XRF spectroscopy, it is estimated that the composite consisted of 43 wt.% REUSY and 57 wt.% AlPO4. Such proportion should be considered for the analysis of their textural properties and the percentage of crystallinity. Fresh AlPO-REUSY presents a type IV isotherm with a significant mesopore volume and a broad pore size distribution with an average size of 142 Å (Fig. 6 ). It is logical to assume that its amount of mesopores comes from AlPO and that micropore volume is only introduced by REUSY content. Considering the predicted value of MiPV calculated for AlPO-REUSY, it can be inferred that the fresh composite suffered a slight loss of MiPV (-10 %) that might be due to some pore blockage. Hydrothermal deactivation causes intense dealumination of REUSY framework, resulting in the increase of mesopore volume at the expense of micropore volume. However, such creation of mesopores in deactivated REUSY cannot fully account for the high retention of mesopores in AlPO-REUSY-d, which preserved 88 % of the mesopore volume relative to its fresh counterpart AlPO-REUSY. It indicates that somehow a significant part of the AlPO remains in the composite without being crystallized after deactivation, thus retaining its mesoporous nature, differently from stand-alone AlPO-d (Fig. 2). Also important, AlPO-REUSY-d has slightly higher MiPV than the predicted value, suggesting some zeolite stabilization imparted by AlPO4 in the composite. X-ray diffraction patterns of fresh and deactivated REUSY and AlPO-REUSY are shown in Fig. 7 . REUSY-d and AlPO-REUSY-d diffractograms indicate that their zeolitic frameworks are preserved despite the loss of intensity in comparison with their respective fresh samples. Although AlPO-REUSY-d presents a slight increase of the signal at 2θ = 21.6° that could be interpreted as some occurrence of AlPO4 as cristobalite phase [35], the predominant signal is the characteristic broad band of amorphous AlPO4 in the 2θ range from 18° to 30° overlapping REUSY-d peaks [8,10], as observed in fresh AlPO-REUSY. It corroborates the remarkable suppression of AlPO crystallization during AlPO-REUSY deactivation, as indirectly evidenced through textural properties described in the previous paragraph. The relative XRD crystallinity of the samples was estimated to investigate the effect of AlPO4 on the zeolitic framework before and after deactivation (Table 5 ). All estimations were normalized by the amount of REUSY in the composite, considering fresh REUSY as 100 %. The preservation of 99.5 % crystallinity in AlPO-REUSY suggests that phosphorus species do not cause noticeable destruction of zeolitic structure during the composite preparation. Furthermore, AlPO-REUSY-d exhibits higher crystallinity retention than REUSY-d. In accordance with textural properties, these results indicate a possible effect of hydrothermal stabilization of REUSY framework promoted by AlPO4. Solid-state MAS NMR spectra are shown in Fig. 8 a-d and the percentage of Al and P species are described in Tables 3 and 4. 1H MAS Hahn-echo spectrum of REUSY shows a peak at 9.4 ppm, assigned to adsorbed water in the form of Al(H2O)6 +3; a shoulder at 6.8 ppm, ascribed to water adsorbed on Lewis acid sites; signals at 4.7 ppm and 3.8 ppm, related to bridging Si−OH-Al groups in sodalite cage and supercage; a signal at 2.9 ppm due to hydroxyls groups bonded to EFAL (Al−OH) and a peak at 1.3 ppm related to non-acidic Si−OH groups (Fig. 8a) [42–44]. In REUSY-d spectrum, the signals at 9.4 ppm and 6.8 ppm are absent due to dehydration. The spectrum of fresh AlPO-REUSY, in comparison with REUSY, exhibits an intensification of the 9.4 ppm peak that can be correlated to the presence of water coming from AlPO4. It can be noticed the attenuation of the signal at 3.8 ppm, which reveals the neutralization of some Brönsted acid sites by P species [45,46]. In AlPO-REUSY-d spectrum, the signal at 3.8 ppm can be clearly detected, showing that the above neutralization was reverted during deactivation. Furthermore, the peak at 9.4 ppm is absent; the signal at 1.3 ppm increases due to the formation of new Si−OH and probably new POH groups [47], and a signal at 0.89 ppm appears, probably related to non-acidic terminal Al−OH groups from AlPO4 [47]. 31P MAS NMR spectra of AlPO-REUSY and AlPO-REUSY-d displayed in Fig. 8b are composed of overlapping peaks at approximately -12, -19, -25 and -30 ppm. The deconvoluted spectra are shown in Fig. S1c-d. In accordance with the literature [15,16], it is noted the formation of more condensed polyphosphate species during deactivation, since the signal at -19 ppm increases whereas the signal at -12 ppm decreases in percentage. Yet, the percentages of P species at -25 and -30 ppm in the fresh and deactivated composites remain similar, indicating that there is minor conversion from amorphous into crystalline aluminum phosphate phases (Table 4). 27Al MAS NMR spectrum of fresh REUSY exhibits resonances at 59 ppm, 31 ppm and 0 ppm, which correspond, respectively, to tetrahedral (Altet-f) [21,42,43], intermediate (Alint) [21,42,43] and octahedral (Aloct) aluminum species [15,16,21,42,43] (Fig. 8c). In fresh AlPO-REUSY spectrum, all resonances related to REUSY and AlPO are detected (section 3.1.1). In addition, the analysis of 27Al 3QMAS in AlPO-REUSY confirmed the presence of distorted tetrahedral Al with high quadrupole constant in the REUSY framework (Aldist-tet-f) [42,48], according to the correlation signal at (42.61 ppm; 42.44 ppm) in Fig. 9 . As compared to the separate zeolite, the peak at 59 ppm (Altet-f) and mainly the one at 0 ppm (Aloct) in AlPO-REUSY suffer reduction, whereas the signal at 39 ppm (Altet-O-P) increases in intensity, considering the percentage of AlPO in the composite (Table 3). This increase must be related to the migration of P species to the proximity of REUSY, creating more Altet-O-P and, consequently, reducing Altet-f and Aloct species [45]. Regarding the deactivated samples, the reduction in the signal at 59 ppm evidences the dealumination process led by hydrothermal deactivation. The percentage of Altet-O-P in AlPO-REUSY-d remains similar to that of fresh AlPO-REUSY, showing that there is minor formation of crystalline aluminum phosphate phases during deactivation, in agreement with 31P MAS NMR spectra. The deconvoluted 27Al MAS NMR spectra of fresh and deactivated REUSY and AlPO-REUSY are shown in Fig. S2a-d. From 29Si MAS NMR spectra of fresh REUSY and AlPO-REUSY (Fig. 8d), it can be noticed peaks at approximately -90, -95, -102 and -107 ppm that correlate with silicon species bonded, respectively, to three [Q4(3Al)], two [Q4(2Al)], one [Q4(1Al)] and zero [Q4(0Al)] Al atoms in the second coordination sphere [21,42]. A shoulder at -112 ppm corresponds to amorphous silicon species formed during zeolite ultra-stabilization and deactivation processes. 29Si MAS NMR spectra were employed for the determination of framework Si/Al ratios, as described elsewhere [49], and values are displayed in Table 5. Framework Si/Al ratio of the fresh composite is unaffected in comparison with fresh REUSY, which corroborates the initial observation that no significant zeolite dealumination is caused by phosphorus during the composite synthesis at low pH. After deactivation, the main difference is the peak at -102 ppm, which is well-defined for AlPO-REUSY-d, but occurs only as a shoulder for REUSY-d. Consequently, AlPO-REUSY-d shows a somewhat lower Si/Al ratio than REUSY-d, which confirms the higher framework aluminum retention provided by amorphous AlPO4 in the composite (Table 5). The deconvoluted 29Si MAS NMR spectra and the integral value of each peak are shown in Supplementary Information, Fig. S3a-d and Table S2. These findings reveal the positive effect of aluminum phosphate, synthesized at stoichiometric Al/P ratio at low pH, when mixed with REUSY, since framework dealumination is attenuated. This effect is related to the migration of polyphosphate species to the zeolite, even in the calcined (fresh) composite, as evidenced by 1H and 27Al MAS NMR results. Data suggest that, during deactivation, P-Altet-f interfaces retard REUSY dealumination, resembling the protective effect of P impregnation on HZSM-5 [15–19]. Studies of Damodaran and coworkers, who analyzed MAS NMR signatures of HZSM-5 modified with 13 wt.% P, showed direct evidence of through-bond Al-O-P connectivities between aluminum (Altet-dist, Alpent and Aloct) and phosphorus species in the deactivated sample, and different structures involving Al-O-P bonds were suggested [38]. In turn, Weckhuysen and coworkers have claimed the occurrence of local framework SAPO (silico-aluminophosphate) interfaces [4,17,45,46,50], formed when phosphate species bond with terminal Si-O-Al−OH groups of partially dislodged Altet generated during thermal treatment, and these interfaces remain unaffected during deactivation, thus preserving Al fixed in the framework [45]. In this sense, the structures presented by Damodaran et al. in [38] are examples of local SAPO interfaces [45]. Other interfaces are possible, since phosphoric acid can coordinate with Altet, inducing Al to assume octahedral coordination [45,46]. Besides, H3PO4 can distort the electronic environment of Altet due to H bonding between H atoms in H3PO4 and framework oxygen and/or Brönsted acid sites and phosphate oxygen groups [45,46]. Remarkably, the present work reveals P-Altet-f interfaces in AlPO-REUSY, which show reversibility during deactivation, according to 1H MAS Hahn-echo spectra and the discussion above in this section. Notwithstanding, the formation of local SAPO centers cannot be confirmed since no expressive peak at -89 ppm is observed in 29Si MAS NMR spectra of the composites. This is the chemical shift characteristic of [Q4(4Al)] species in SAPO-37, which is iso-structural with faujasite [21,51,52]. The preservation of framework Si/Al ratio in the fresh composite also suggests the absence of SAPO interfaces. In order to confirm bonding between P and framework Al, Weckhuysen et al. suggested performing J-coupling 27Al-29Si correlation MAS NMR spectroscopy in combination with J-coupling 27Al-31P correlation MAS NMR spectroscopy [45]. Another relevant consequence of the AlPO4-REUSY interaction is the inhibition of AlPO4 crystallization during deactivation. Since AlPO4 crystallization occurs via condensation of −OH groups, as shown in Section 3.1.1 (Fig. 5a), its suppression must be related to the retention of these groups in polyphosphates. The formation of additional EFAL-bonded polyphosphates in the deactivated composite supports this hypothesis, according to 27Al and 31P MAS NMR data (Tables 4–5). It is suggested that bonding involving EFAL and phosphate oxygen groups is energetically more favorable than the condensation of those hydroxyl groups in the conditions of this study. Moreover, it can be noticed that, in comparison with fresh AlPO, the resonances of P species in AlPO-REUSY shifted to lower frequencies (Fig. S1a, S1c), indicating the existence of different types of interaction which may improve the stability of polyphosphates and amorphous AlPO4 under deactivation. Further experiments would be necessary for a detailed description of the location of P species on the zeolite particles, as well as for the investigation of the thermal transformations of these species, relating them to the suppression of AlPO4 crystallization. 3.2 Pilot plant-scale catalysts Physical-chemical and textural properties of the fresh and deactivated catalysts are presented in Tables 6 and 7 , respectively. Attrition index (AI) is reported as a dimensionless value related to mechanical properties of catalyst microspheres; the higher the AI value, the lower the attrition resistance [53]. The average diameter of a FCC catalyst particle is about 70 μm and particles of any component greater than 8 μm cannot be effectively bound into a particle of such diameter [2]. Then, the higher AI value found in CAT-P is likely justified by the presence of large AlPO4 clusters, up to 15 μm in size, inside the catalyst particle, as can be observed in the field emission SEM image (Fig. S4). Ongoing investigation should tackle this drawback and improve catalyst mechanical resistance either by pre-milling AlPO4 or by changing AlPO4 sol-gel chemistry via addition of complexing/modifying organic agents [10,14], aiming to avoid aggregation of primary particles and, consequently, minimizing the formation of AlPO4 clusters [54]. Textural properties of the spray-dried catalysts confirm the main findings observed in the lab-scale REUSY-AlPO composites. The significantly higher mesopore volume of CAT-P, compared to CAT-A and CAT-R, confirms the retention of the existing mesoporous structure in AlPO4. This mesoporosity is largely retained after deactivation of CAT-P, even in the presence of the contaminant metals (nickel and vanadium). CAT-P presents a micropore volume lower than the other fresh catalysts, most likely due to pore blockage caused by polyphosphates species, as discussed in Section 3.1.2. However, after deactivation, the micropore volume of CAT-P-d becomes closer to that of CAT-R-d and CAT-A-d counterparts, indicating the preservation of zeolitic framework, in agreement with XRD and MAS NMR data of the lab-scale samples (Section 3.1.2). The number of Brönsted acid sites in the deactivated catalysts without contaminant metals was measured by n-propylamine-TPD in order to observe the influence of active matrices on catalyst acidity. As a proof of concept to verify the creation of Brönsted acid sites through silica and alumina interaction, another catalyst without silica binder (40 wt.% REUSY, 20 wt.% Al2O3 and 40 wt.% kaolin), named CAT-Ak-d, was prepared and deactivated in the same way as the other catalysts as described in Section 2.2 and also analyzed by n-propylamine-TPD to be compared with the counterpart with silica-alumina (CAT-A-d). The TPD results are shown in Table 8 , with a relative experimental error of ± 10 %. Data relative to TPD profiles are found in Fig. S5 and Table S3. Further characterization of CAT-Ak is shown in Table S4. The TPD results show the increase in Brönsted acid sites in the catalysts containing active matrices, in comparison with the reference catalyst CAT-R-d. CAT-A-d presents a higher number of acid sites in comparison with CAT-Ak-d, which can be assigned to the creation of additional sites through the interaction between silica and alumina at high temperatures, as expected [2,5]. In its turn, the higher acidity of CAT-Ak-d in relation to CAT-R-d can be justified by the generation of Brönsted acidity when pseudoboehmite is converted into gamma-alumina at high temperatures, as observed in this work (Table S4, Fig. S6), in accordance with the literature [55,56]. The higher acidity found for CAT-P-d, in relation with CAT-R-d, can be attributed to the Bronsted acidity of AlPO4 (Section 3.1.1) combined with the hydrothermal stabilization of REUSY framework promoted by P species (Section 3.1.2). On the other hand, it is unlikely that interaction between AlPO4 and SiO2 occurs in the matrix phase generating Brönsted acid sites, since theoretical studies have shown the high instability of Si-O-P bonds [57,58]. Although CAT-A-d and CAT-P-d presented a similar amount of Brönsted acid sites, they can differ in terms of feedstock conversion and catalytic performance, since these features depend on the distribution of Brönsted acid sites in the zeolite and matrix phases. 3.3 Catalytic evaluation The deactivated catalysts were tested by vacuum gas oil cracking in an ACE unit. The data are shown in Table 9 . Each value represents the average of five measurements plus or minus one standard deviation calculated from this set of measurements. Feedstock conversion (wt.%) is defined as [100 – (LCO + bottoms)] [59]. Mass balances ranged between 95.8 and 101.8 wt.%. Higher levels of feedstock conversion obtained with CAT-P and CAT-A, compared with CAT-R, evidence the crucial role of matrix for the FCC catalyst performance. The existence of Brönsted acid sites on the surface of amorphous AlPO4 enables its use as matrix in FCC catalysts leading to the pre-cracking of the heavy molecules, whereas its large mesoporous volume ensures the effective transport of reactants and products to and from the active zeolite sites [3]. Nevertheless, the better performance of CAT-A-d, exhibiting the highest conversion and the lowest bottoms amount, can be attributed to a higher number of Brönsted acid sites on the alumina-based matrix, in comparison to AlPO4, which resulted in a more active matrix. With the addition of nickel and vanadium, the performance of CAT-R-i becomes worse when compared to its counterparts containing matrices: CAT-R-i shows the highest drop in conversion and the highest increase in bottoms relative to the deactivated catalyst without the contaminant metals. Although not supported by the textural characterization (Table 7), catalytic results clearly suggest the metals tolerance effect provided by both matrices [1,6]. Moreover, the average drop in feedstock conversion between CAT-P-d and CAT-P-i (0.8 wt.%) is lower than that between CAT-A-d and CAT-A-i (1.5 wt.%), indicating that the presence of AlPO4 leads to slightly higher retention of activity after catalyst impregnation with the contaminant metals. CAT-P-d and CAT-A-d exhibit similar naphtha and LCO yields; the slight differences are within the standard deviation range. However, dividing product yield by conversion, i.e., calculating the selectivity to this product, it is seen that CAT-P-d is more selective to naphtha (65.3 %) than CAT-A-d (63.0 %) and CAT-P-d is also more selective to LCO (25.8 %) than CAT-A-d (24.6 %). Additionally, CAT-P-d presents lower olefins yields and slightly lower LPG/naphtha ratios in relation to alumina-containing catalyst. The same trend is observed in CAT-P-i and CAT-A-i pair. Hence, the catalytic evaluation indicates that CAT-P-d and CAT-A-d generate different distributions of products in the liquid and gas phases, even though these catalysts have a similar amount of Brönsted acid sites (Table 8). Among the deactivated catalysts without Ni and V, coke yields increase with conversion. However, a ranking inversion occurs under the presence of contaminant metals, with CAT-P-i producing more coke than CAT-A-i. Likewise, CAT-P-i also resulted in worse selectivity to hydrogen and fuel gas than CAT-A-i, with higher yields at lower feedstock conversion. The product selectivity in the naphtha fractions, determined by PIANIO analysis, is shown in Table 10 . Considering naphtha yields (Table 9), CAT-P-d and CAT-P-i promoted an increase in isoparaffins and aromatics yields in the naphtha fractions, in detriment of olefins, when compared with the respective alumina-containing catalysts. CAT-P-d promoted an increase of 6 % and 3 % in isoparaffins and aromatics yields, respectively, in relation to CAT-A-d. In its turn, CAT-P-i promoted a relative increase of 2 % in aromatics yields towards CAT-A-i. The increase in MON (motor octane number) is also observed for CAT-P-d and CAT-P-i. Although CAT-R-d and CAT-R-i present high selectivity to aromatics, these catalysts have the lowest selectivity to naphtha, which results in lower aromatics yields. Compared with CAT-A, CAT-P promotes a different distribution of products, with the increase in aromatics yields in the liquid phase and the decrease in olefins yields in the gas and liquid phases. Accordingly, these results indicate that CAT-P presents an increased hydrogen transfer reaction rate, which follows a bimolecular reaction mechanism [60,61]. Olefins, the reactive species in naphtha for secondary reactions, are consumed in H-transfer reactions before being cracked to generate LPG fractions. Since catalytic coke formation also follows a bimolecular reaction mechanism, its yield tends to increase with the hydrogen transfer rate [60,61]. The increase in the rate of hydrogen transfer reactions implies that CAT-P retains a higher number of zeolitic Brönsted acid sites after deactivation. Thus, it can be concluded that, although CAT-A-d and CAT-P-d have similar number of Brönsted acid sites (Section 3.2), they differ in terms of Brönsted acid site distribution. CAT-A-d has relatively higher contribution of Brönsted sites derived from the matrix due to the occurrence of surface SiO2-Al2O3 sites [2,5], which results in a strong ability to crack heavy oils. In its turn, CAT-P-d has relatively higher contribution of Brönsted sites derived from REUSY framework due to the greater effect of P species attenuating REUSY dealumination, leading to a weaker ability to crack heavy oils, but a higher selectivity to naphtha and LCO. 4 Conclusions The present work has shown that amorphous, mesoporous and stoichiometric aluminum phosphate is an effective active matrix for fluid catalytic cracking catalysts. It has been demonstrated a mutual interaction between AlPO4 and Y zeolite in a composite with mass ratio of approximately 1:1. Migration of polyphosphate species towards the zeolitic structure, even in the calcined composite was detected, and the occurrence of phosphorus-bridging hydroxyl interfaces, reversible under hydrothermal deactivation, was confirmed. These interactions avoided AlPO4 crystallization and ensured its catalytic properties. The deactivated composite retained 88 % of the mesopore volume existent in the fresh sample, an effect that could not be explained by Y zeolite dealumination, nor by the stand-alone AlPO4, which changed into a non-porous, crystalline phase under deactivation. Moreover, AlPO4 improved zeolite stabilization and enhanced the retention of Brönsted acid sites during the composite deactivation. The deactivated composite presented a Si/Al ratio of 9.7, whereas the pure deactivated REUSY had a higher Si/Al ratio of 10.3. As a consequence of the mutual AlPO4-Y zeolite interaction, the catalyst prepared with AlPO4, in comparison with the alumina-containing catalyst, presented a higher rate of hydrogen transfer reactions during vacuum gas oil cracking, leading to the increase in isoparaffins and aromatics yields, thus promoting improved motor octane number in the naphtha fraction. A relative increase of 6% and 3% in isoparaffins and aromatics yields, respectively, was observed for the AlPO4-containing catalyst without nickel and vanadium contaminant metals, whereas a relative increase of 2% in aromatics yields was promoted by AlPO4 in the impregnated catalyst. Alumina- and AlPO4-containing catalysts generated similar liquid product yields. Although AlPO4 was less effective than alumina in bottoms conversion, the AlPO4-containing catalyst was more selective to naphtha and LCO yields and showed a higher retention of activity after impregnation with the contaminant metals. Fluid catalytic cracking catalysts containing aluminum phosphate as active matrix are potential alternative materials for increasing liquid yields, as well as increasing isoparaffins and aromatics fractions, targeting automotive and petrochemical industries. Besides, this new catalyst can be an attractive material for reactions involving more easily crackable feedstock, such as renewable sources. coredata.dc:description: The development of new matrices can improve the hydrothermal stability of fluid catalytic cracking catalysts and provide better selectivity to cracking products. Amorphous, mesoporous and stoichiometric aluminum phosphate (AlPO4) was investigated as active matrix to achieve these purposes. In its gel form, the material was initially added to ultra-stabilized Y zeolite to generate composites with mass ratio of about 1:1. The interaction between AlPO4 and Y zeolite avoided AlPO4 crystallization during steaming and increased framework aluminum retention, preserving more Brönsted acid sites. A spray-dried catalyst containing AlPO4 was steam deactivated and tested by vacuum gas oil cracking, being compared with an alumina-containing catalyst and a reference without active matrix. AlPO4-containing catalyst presented tolerance to contaminant metals, higher selectivity to naphtha yields and exhibited a higher hydrogen transfer reaction rate, leading to the increase in isoparaffins and aromatics yields and the increase in the motor octane number in the cracked naphtha.
coredata.dc:title: Aluminum phosphate as active matrix of fluid catalytic cracking catalysts: Y zeolite stabilization
